reviewText:
GAME HIGHLIGHTS :

1. Retro Pixel based Style, exploration mystery solving.

2. Amazing story. Multiple endings. Good for 3-4 gameplays.

3.Somewhat Dynamic level generation. You find new stuff in each gameplay

MY 2 CENTS:

If you lovegames for their stories more then mindless shooting and violence. Go ahead and buy this... Leaves you in such an awesome hangover that would keep you thinking hours after you finish it.

Here is something really awesome about this game, when it ends it doesn't tells you what happened finally and how all the things fit together. It asks you questions and you answer Yes or No. Effectively it is making you tell a story to yourself. and that is the absolute brilliance of this game.

It just takes over an hour to finish the game, so you can play it multiple times without committing too much time. For a dollar a piece this is just a steal for having an out of the world experience in gaming.

reviewText: It bills itself as a horror game. It does not manage to instill horror once, it's just too slow, janky and boring for that (especially since it's told in the past tense so you know the protagonist is still alive). Worse, it is made by either a bloody newbie and ignorant in horror, or by someone actively trying to capitalize on markiplier and pewdiepie. I say this because it contains a number of very egregious jumpscares. As in, it tells you to put on headphones and plays quiet sounds so you turn them up, then slams doors or explodes pipes next to you entirely out of nowhere.\n\nDon't spend money on it. Don't spend time on it.

reviewText: A 2D walking simulator where absolutely nothing scary happens. You walk to the left, sometimes to the right, open doors, and press A next to things with a white box around them.\n\nEverything you examine and/or pick up is presented as some kind of clue" that potentially explains some aspect of the aftermath in which you now find yourself
date: so for the whole game it seems like you are piecing together some kind of mystery. Usually in a mystery game you put together all of the clues and evidence and ultimately conclude what happened. But HOME just shows you a series of items in a sequence and then asks
recommended: "What do YOU think explains this item? A or B?" There is no way to honestly know the answer one way or the other
hoursPlayed: so you just pick one at random. It really doesn't matter what you pick
helpfulPercent:
"That is an interesting theory.The end."

REALLY?

The game is essentially a 50-minute long opinion survey about itself. It takes a sharp turn away from being a pretentious indie game and instead veers headlong in the direction of being an oddly narcissistic one. Can a game be narcissistic? I wouldn't have thought so
votesHelpful: but HOME has made a persuasive argument that it can.\n\nAlso
votesTotal:
there was a point in the game where the controller vibrated non-stop for ten straight minutes for no apparent reason. I almost quit there just to maintain feeling in my hands.

The only positive things I can really say about it are these:

1) The game does have a pretty good atmosphere.

2) It's an interesting narrative experiment
votesFunny: even if I personally consider it a failed one."

reviewText: Home начинается как каждый второй хоррор: мы просыпаемся в мрачном незнакомом доме, на полу лежит изувеченное тело, а в трясущихся руках — только фонарик. Что произошло и как он здесь оказался, наш герой, естественно, не помнит. Но уже через пятнадцать минут блуждания по пиксельным коридорам начинаешь замечать, что в привычной формуле что-то не так, ведь вокруг нет ни души. Предчувствие скорой беды, неизменно присутствующее в завязке любого ужастика, в Home растянуто до финальных титров.

reviewText:
Very deep game with an interesting plot. Your choices don't really matter as much as you think they will. Only important choices are two near the end.

The ending, however, is the best part. You basically have to infer what happens, in your own way. There's actually a website dedicated for people to share what they THOUGHT happened.

Short game, no replay value, but worth the price.

reviewText: Those who complain about the lack of action in this game are doing nothing more than showing the ignorance that they adorn proudly. Home is an interesting indie game about a man who wakes up with no memory of how he got to his current position and makes his way back home, piecing together the events through clues found on his trail. This game has no action, it is simply walking and reading, then making choices. That may not sound fun but it might just surprise you. The best description for this game would be an atmospheric psycological adventure game. Through your actions you shape the ending of the story in a number of ways. BUT, the ending isn't in your face" it is left open for interpertation by the player. If you are into those mindless zombie shooters with no goal or story
date: then keep walking because this game is not for you..."

reviewText:
A lot of the time in the horror genre you realise you have to step through five bad efforts in order to find one good game, and a lot of the time the good/great/classics aren't quite what you expected.

Did I believe that I'd admire the work behind Rob Zombie's House of 1,000 Corpses as a nod to late 60s/early 70s brutal horror tropes and no holds barred content? No, but somehow a brutal charm was found in Bill Moseley's character madness, sure, he may have been paraded in gore but something sinister & evil beyond the basic tropes copy & paste mold used (and improved on with the sequel, The Devil's Rejects) saturated the entire film reel.

Did I believe the Living Dead at the Manchester Morgue was going to be one of the stellar titles of the zombie genre? No, but it stands as one of the creepiest and doom funneled films I've seen. Slowly twisting familiar stories into a new mythos, calling back to days of voodoo and speculation on how science melds with myth.

Home is not filled with gore or sadistic action, this game is understated, it is basic, it's simple, it's atmospheric, it rides on the cinematography of the camera and the ambience of the audio. For what the game may lack in terms of buttons -Home only uses the directional pad and one button- it makes up for in what it makes you see in your own mind.

Is something following you? Are you hunting someone down? Are you condemning yourself wrongly? Is there a monster in your shadow or is it all a fever dream?

Spectacular, I could not recommend this enough. Whether you're an experienced gamer or someone new to games as a whole.

reviewText: Home is an interesting case. It's certainly not great, not even good, but as an experience, is worth a look. The game doesn't tell you where to go, there's no music, and has no other gameplay besides collecting different objects and simply looking around. It could have worked better if it was more psychological about it, by adding a monster to get you, but plays on the part of that says that there is something out there after you, even when you know there isn't. Your simply a child running away from the mystical boogeyman that trying to get you and don't know when. The environment and sounds are well-crafted and quite subtle. Pick it up if your looking for an inexpensive, tense experience, pick it up.

reviewText: Home is a pixelated horror game that I really enjoyed. The gameplay is rather intutiive and consists of moving your character and selecting items for puzzles. A run-through is a about an hour and a half. Replayability is somewhat limited but making different choices and getting different endings is interesting. The puzzles were enjoyable and kept major back tracking to a minimum. The graphics are pixelated which I really enjoyed due to the dark nature of the game. There is no music in the game only sound effects. The sound effects are great and really build suspense and dread.\n\nThe game's plot is not linear and is up to interpretation, especially the ending. The game focuses on the player's choices and psychology. Although the game is labeled as horror"
date: the game is more about dread and the atmosphere of the unknown. This is not a game about jumpscares or scary monsters

reviewText: Home начинается как каждый второй хоррор: мы просыпаемся в мрачном незнакомом доме, на полу лежит изувеченное тело, а в трясущихся руках — только фонарик. Но уже через пятнадцать минут блуждания по пиксельным коридорам начинаешь замечать, что в привычной формуле что-то не так, ведь вокруг нет ни души. Предчувствие скорой беды, неизменно присутствующее в завязке любого ужастика, в Home растянуто до финальных титров.

reviewText:
Hmm... very torn about this game. (Relly wish there was an option for that, dang it!)

On one hand gives a very good spooky vibe of suspense that something may be coming after you at some point. The story throughout the game changes depending what you find and if you decide to pick up certain items or not. Trying to figure out what happened, what lead up to it, and if the decisions you make have an impact on the storytelling. May require you to replay it a few times to understand what fully happened, or if you may have overlooked something.

On the other, short and eventually the suspense dies out about a 1/4 way. Granted the dev team did recommend you play it throughly in one sitting, and they did say it would be 1.5 hours long at the start of the game. But for a $3 game, it's a very good price for it.

I do recommend this to those that may get easily spooked and new to horror games, as this is just a small taste of it but without the frosting on the cupcake. You're only getting a muffin, and those are good too!

I don't recommend it to veteran horror gamers and fans as this would bore them quickly and feel they wasted their money, which isn't much.

reviewText:
Can't really recommend.  The transition animation from room-to-room was irritating enough that I won't even attempt to play through the game again to try for a different ending.  When the animations between rooms, which are basically all the same, account for nearly 10% of the game play time, you're trying too hard to fill out the game.

Also, the ending I got was ... really uninteresting.  It couldn't have felt like more of a let down without actually not having an ending.  I did like the concept and I think it was mostly there, but the annoying room transitions, the ending let down, and yet another blah pixel look game just keep it from being worth a buy.

6 of 15 muffins.

reviewText:
Simply chilling and thrilling, Home is a pixel horror that is not about running away from monsters, but doing so in your head. It is a mental game with many puzzles and although called a walking simulator, it is much, much more...

Grapics- 8/10 Why so high you might ask? Well the atmosphere of the game is great and it ties in with the graphics.

Controls-10/10 Simple. Easy.

Handling- 9/10 You can feel yourself in the characters shoes.

Story- 3/10 Not much here. If there was more meat on the bone I would have loved it but i cant say I knew what was going on at one or two points, basicly you are just trying to get home at night.

Gameplay- 9/10 The reason for this being so high is that your character will have thoughts about your choices, and not even major ones. If you take the gun he is scaired because he think he will kill himself, or drop it/give away his position, etc.

Creativity- 8/10 Done before but never like this.

Price-10/10

Hype-10/10 Better that expected.

Overall- 8/10 The choice is your's to make, but for real $3 bucks is like a gallon of gas, just buy it!

It was okay. Maybe I just didn't make the right choices, but I didn't find this game particularly fun — I got pretty bored, to be honest. Nor did I find the ending satisfying, interesting, or impactful.

I also didn't appreciate how they executed the choices that determine the details of the ending. Asking the player what to have the player character do is one thing. Asking the player what the results of those actions were, or what someone else did — which is what it started doing near the end — is something else entirely.

There are many doorways and branching paths, so I got lost a lot, which wouldn't have been so bad if I'd been given the freedom to explore fully. But sometimes I would go through a certain door only to be told that I couldn't go back, or that the character didn't want to go back. That would have been nice to know before I went there, that way I could have gone back and explored the rest of the area. I understand that a story where your choices determine the ending is one where you will have to forego one path in order to take another, but I would have appreciated some warning before the game made those decisions for me. Otherwise I'm not really the one choosing what happens.

The game did not make it clear when my actions had been effective. An example: Turning a valve. If it needed to be turned again, I'd expect the character to state this out loud, without my needing to examine the valve again. I don't think I've ever played a game where this wasn't the case. But in fact, it wasn't until I went where I was trying to make the water level descend and saw that it hadn't worked, then went back and examined the valve again, that the character told me that there was still water running through the pipe.

Lastly, as I approached the end, the game made sure to make me regret my choices by bringing up things I could have done but didn't. It felt like the game was giving me the finger for not doing the right thing"

I found this game to be unsatisfying. I am completely for player choice in games and I can see what this game was trying to do, points for trying. But I felt I had no guidance to ensure a coherent narrative. By the end of the choice section, the story summary I received was nonsensical and ridiculous. Otherwise, I thought the game was okay. Good looking game, good sound, plays smoothly. The atmosphere started out creepy, but I quickly got accustomed and the game made no attempt to intensify things. For most of my playthrough I was bored and then I finished up as very confused. It's only about an hour long.
very interesting but a lot of things are left unasnwered, leaving you to draw conclusions yourself.

It was okay. Maybe I just didn't make the right choices, but I didn't find this game particularly fun — I got pretty bored, to be honest. Nor did I find the ending satisfying, interesting, or impactful.

I also didn't appreciate how they executed the choices that determine the details of the ending. Asking the player what to have the player character do is one thing. Asking the player what the results of those actions were, or what someone else did — which is what it started doing near the end — is something else entirely.

There are many doorways and branching paths, so I got lost a lot, which wouldn't have been so bad if I'd been given the freedom to explore fully. But sometimes I would go through a certain door only to be told that I couldn't go back, or that the character didn't want to go back. That would have been nice to know before I went there, that way I could have gone back and explored the rest of the area. I understand that a story where your choices determine the ending is one where you will have to forego one path in order to take another, but I would have appreciated some warning before the game made those decisions for me. Otherwise I'm not really the one choosing what happens.

The game did not make it clear when my actions had been effective. An example: Turning a valve. If it needed to be turned again, I'd expect the character to state this out loud, without my needing to examine the valve again. I don't think I've ever played a game where this wasn't the case. But in fact, it wasn't until I went where I was trying to make the water level descend and saw that it hadn't worked, then went back and examined the valve again, that the character told me that there was still water running through the pipe.

Lastly, as I approached the end, the game made sure to make me regret my choices by bringing up things I could have done but didn't. It felt like the game was giving me the finger for not doing the right thing"

reviewText:
Home is a essentially a horror story game. Your character wakes up and has to embark on a journey picking up clues on the way to his home.
The game isn't actually scary, it seems scary because of the dark environment and you holding a flashligt that only illuminates a small radiaus.

The game actually has different endings, I found 2 but only finished one and the one ending that I found isn't the happy one.

Overall a good quality story game.
Compelling and thought provoking! A very good story driven game that is good for a few playthroughs and some non stressful gameplay.\n\n9/10
Very short, and I couldn't wait for it to be over.  Disappointed in this one, I just didn't get it at all.

This shouldn't be called horror, and that's its biggest mistake, if you ask me.

For many, I suspect, horror involves more explicit terrifying elements than corpses and the shifting sounds of buildings. In this respect, this game is far more of a psychological thriller than it is a horror game. Perhaps, it might be said, this is one of the very few thriller titles to be found in games, since it makes the decision to exclude both combat and any direct enemy confrontations. As other reviews indicate, despite mentioning that you choose the ending, the absence of any indication of whether you truly confront the cause of all the events led them to disappointment.

However, while I can understand this perspective, I think that the game stands up well enough on its own, with the interesting use of interaction with objects influencing the narrative, to get by with this. In fact, the very real recognition of your presence at certain points makes this an especially interesting title to me, whereas for others it seemed a copout. It wasn't the most graceful integration of the player's involvement, admittedly, but it was closer in tune to what I had hoped Deadly Premonition would do, if familiar with that title.

Either way, for as cheap and short as it is, and for what seems to me very decent quality (sound design/writing/artistically), I'd say this title is a steal if you're interested in games that experiment with interactive narratives.
NAH

(Warning: I discuss spoilers. Play the game first if you're interested,  it takes 90 minutes.)

My approach to this game was wrong.

I had a restless night to kill, I had only my Macbook, and needed something graphics-lite I could play with my keyboard. Home seemed like the perfect fit.

It seemed set up as an adventure game with an easy interface. Great! I found myself quickly analyzing clues, trying to piece together what was happening. That being said, the game doesn't challenge you to *actually* understand much of anything - and so my character's frequent questions about what he was looking at just fed the sense of mystery.

I was expecting answers. That's not a good start.

The atmosphere is generally unsettling because the game teaches you very early on that the game's volume is on 5 and the game's audio jump scares are on THIRTY MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING TWO. I turned down the whole thing and ruined the atmosphere just to save myself a heart attack. But it's a cheap parlor trick - nothing ever comes out of the shadows, it's just noises.

There are many choices you can make. Do I pick up the bloody knife or leave it? Well, I seemed to be an amnesiac in an unknown environment with dead bodies everywhere, so yeah, I'll take the knife. I'd hate for something else to take the knife and kill me with it. My character then muses, Did I really need this knife?" ..... Well now wait a minute
date: I thought I was being practical. Am I just being paranoid? Does the game think I'm a violent person now?\n\nI picked up the knife
hoursPlayed: I picked up most objects that seemed useful. And some objects I decided seemed pointless wound up being typical adventure key items. Why am I given the choice to pick it up or not if I need it to progress? Seems strange. What do my choices even mean?\n\nSo I get to the end

A very short game/story, where you wake up with memory loss and a murder has taken place. Not exactly the most original story.

You then walk around the environments, learning stuff and deciding what has happened. At the end you can share your story and learn other people’s perspective of the story. Sound is used well. The text is interesting to read.

I didn't get much out of the experience. It’s an unclear and meaingless story where the story makes pretty much every possibility possible. This is my least favourite type of story, because for me it feels lazy and incomplete.

This is an attempt at video game art that could've been great, but ultimately failed in execution. The whole experience builds up to something - and then there is no real finale, no climax, no point d'orgue.\nI do not recommend this game, because you will be disappointed. Instead, let's wait for Benjamin Rivers' next project. He has proven to be capable of producing great games, I hope he will produce a completed and self-contained experience with his next game.

A short (hour, hour and a half) game where you wake up to discover something bad has possibly happened. But what?  Your decisions throughout the exploration determine what the final story is. When the game is over, you can go to the dev's web page and compare your story's outcome to those of other players. Pretty cool. I don't want to give anything away, but it's pretty creepy and I think the story's outcome tells a bit about the person who is playing the game, and I find this quite intriguing. I definitely recommend this.

This game was okay, but by no means perfect. I think it definitely justifies its price tag, but I wouldn't buy it again given the choice. THe game plays out like sidescrolling text adventure, to be honest. There's a lack of any type of puzzle, and the focus is on the story. Which was probably a good decision because the story is... decent? It wasn't mind blowing, but it worked for what the game was. I'll admit Home had me backing away from my computer (in fear) a few times, but there weren't any huge scares. The biggest scares came from jump scares in the background, cheap grabs done to make you jump. All in all, this game was an okay playthrough, but I doub't I'll ever touch it again. 5/10.

It was okay. Maybe I just didn't make the right choices, but I didn't find this game particularly fun — I got pretty bored, to be honest. Nor did I find the ending satisfying, interesting, or impactful.

I also didn't appreciate how they executed the choices that determine the details of the ending. Asking the player what to have the player character do is one thing. Asking the player what the results of those actions were, or what someone else did — which is what it started doing near the end — is something else entirely.

There are many doorways and branching paths, so I got lost a lot, which wouldn't have been so bad if I'd been given the freedom to explore fully. But sometimes I would go through a certain door only to be told that I couldn't go back, or that the character didn't want to go back. That would have been nice to know before I went there, that way I could have gone back and explored the rest of the area. I understand that a story where your choices determine the ending is one where you will have to forego one path in order to take another, but I would have appreciated some warning before the game made those decisions for me. Otherwise I'm not really the one choosing what happens.

The game did not make it clear when my actions had been effective. An example: Turning a valve. If it needed to be turned again, I'd expect the character to state this out loud, without my needing to examine the valve again. I don't think I've ever played a game where this wasn't the case. But in fact, it wasn't until I went where I was trying to make the water level descend and saw that it hadn't worked, then went back and examined the valve again, that the character told me that there was still water running through the pipe.

Lastly, as I approached the end, the game made sure to make me regret my choices by bringing up things I could have done but didn't. It felt like the game was giving me the finger for not doing the right thing"

Kind of interesting story-thriller. I bought this 1. Because it was on sale and 2. Because it was billed as a retro styled horror game. The sale was good because if I paid any more for the game I'd probably be pretty upset. I completed one playthrough, it took less than an hour. Calling this game a horror game is a big stretch. You play a guy with a flashlight and interact with nothing but inanimate objects the entire game, making simple choices, pick this up? read this? turn this on? It's story driven. You do a lot of reading but it's not a lot of tedious reading, a couple sentences at a time. The good news is your choices effect the final outcome of the game. The bad news is, it  wasn't nearly interesting enough for me to play through again any time soon, maybe at a later date.

[SPOILERS AHEAD. SPOILERS!]

I appreciated that you get to kind of pick your ending, in the way that I appreciate it almost any time a game gives me a decision, but since it wasn't as free roaming as I would have liked (I can't solve a mystery until I realize there is a mystery game) and the fact that I was continually nudged along, the huge plot twist being up to me made the game feel... pointless?

Like, if I wanted to write another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ psychological horror about an insane alcoholic I could have done this myself.

I think the game would have been vastly more interesting to me if it weren't just another white man with problems who is trying to rescue a woman (plot twist being either that he killed her or she was made up in his head wooo boy wow such twist much psychological).

It's a stupid cheap game, so I guess I recommend it if you really like stories about white men gaining agency.

But otherwise, even at this price? You can pass.

An 8-bit masterpiece! Anyone with a taste for murder mystery, people with amnesia, and surprises around every corner HAS to play this. You can choose your own adventure, if you want it to be a happy ending so be it, if not make it that way. It is a neccessity to play. 10/10!

Home is a game meant to be played in one sitting. It takes around an hour to complete (longer if you enjoy exploring every nook and cranny).

That being said I think it does a wonderful job of keeping the player intrigued and involved throughout the entire game. The story paired with the retro graphics keeps the player on the edge of their seat, and thus makes the game that much more enjoyable.

If you are looking for a way to spend about an hour and you enjoy suspensful stories, then I'd certainly recommend Home as it is worth the price.

A bland, contrived, mess of a non-game.

I did everything the game asked me to.  I turned off all the lights, put on my headphones and set aside and hour and a half to enjoy what would be a spooky, artistic adventure.  In turn what I got was an interactive story without scares or resolution.  Typically I'm fine with having the gameplay take the backseat to a good story, but this game was just so boring and all the plot points were purposfully ambiguous.

In the end, what should amount to an intruiging little who done it" fell flat on it's face when the game actually asks you "so what do you think happened?".

This is not good storytelling.  This game is a failure on every front."

Going onto this game, I expected jumpscares and cheap thrills. I have recieved quite the opposite.

Home is a game that doesnt rely on loud noises and pop-ups. It uses subtlety and emotions to make you feel uncomfortable the whole way through. The whole playthrough I felt off and as if something was going to happen at any moment. The suspense was killing me and I feel that it worked greatly. The game delves into psychology and picks away at your defenses slowly until you aren't sure what's going to happen anymore.

I understand that a lot of people don't like this game and have given it terrible reviews. However I insist that you consider playing it for the above reasons.

reviewText: It's basically a narrative game you interact with every single object.\nThe game is so linear, it's boring.

You wake up in a strange room and find a few dead bodies. Bad thing is, you can't remember anything and the murderer could still be around. Well... not really... I think at this point it is clear that you are the murderer. But okay, let's pretend we don't know. You start waaaaaaalking from room to room just to discover more dead bodies and personal items of your own. A lot of personal items... It's like you walked through your house the night before, filled up a big bag of random stuff and spread it all around town afterwards. And now you've got to pick all the stuff back up. At the end your character is drawing some conclusions probably based on the stuff you've picked up ealier. And THAT IS ALL.

1. Walk around.
2. Pick up any random item. (Confirm the hell out of your Y-Botton)
3. Get confronted with dead bodies and names you have never heard of.
4. Repeat.

Boring as hell. Almost at the end of the game, you are confronted with the first real riddle. It's a safe and you are literally getting no hints whatsoever how to unlock the damn thing. Frustrated, I looked the combination up on google and you know what? You really don't get any hint, it's just written into the game's manual. Btw it's 4R3UHER3

Home is a short and story rich game. The main character wakes up with seemingly no memories.

The player's job is to explore and find clues about what's happened. There's some replay value, if you want to try leaving behind an item you picked up the first time or if you managed to miss an area or a room. There are some statements the game wants the player to confirm or deny at the end to summarize the story. Although as far as I know the story is up to interpretation.

To me this was decent fun for 2 hours (played through it twice) and I recommend the game if you want to try solving a mystery
Boring and lacks a coherent ending. its more about the horror experience of a character with amnesia who finds his dead coworker and wife.

reviewText: Interesting take on a generic story...\nAll too predictable and pretty short either way. Buy on sale if you really wanna play.

A very short game/story, where you wake up with memory loss and a murder has taken place. Not exactly the most original story.

You then walk around the environments, learning stuff and deciding what has happened. At the end you can share your story and learn other people’s perspective of the story. Sound is used well. The text is interesting to read.

I didn't get much out of the experience. It’s an unclear and meaingless story where the story makes pretty much every possibility possible. This is my least favourite type of story, because for me it feels lazy and incomplete.

(Warning: I discuss spoilers. Play the game first if you're interested,  it takes 90 minutes.)

My approach to this game was wrong.

I had a restless night to kill, I had only my Macbook, and needed something graphics-lite I could play with my keyboard. Home seemed like the perfect fit.

It seemed set up as an adventure game with an easy interface. Great! I found myself quickly analyzing clues, trying to piece together what was happening. That being said, the game doesn't challenge you to *actually* understand much of anything - and so my character's frequent questions about what he was looking at just fed the sense of mystery.

I was expecting answers. That's not a good start.

The atmosphere is generally unsettling because the game teaches you very early on that the game's volume is on 5 and the game's audio jump scares are on THIRTY MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING TWO. I turned down the whole thing and ruined the atmosphere just to save myself a heart attack. But it's a cheap parlor trick - nothing ever comes out of the shadows, it's just noises.

There are many choices you can make. Do I pick up the bloody knife or leave it? Well, I seemed to be an amnesiac in an unknown environment with dead bodies everywhere, so yeah, I'll take the knife. I'd hate for something else to take the knife and kill me with it. My character then muses, Did I really need this knife?" ..... Well now wait a minute
date: I thought I was being practical. Am I just being paranoid? Does the game think I'm a violent person now?\n\nI picked up the knife
hoursPlayed: I picked up most objects that seemed useful. And some objects I decided seemed pointless wound up being typical adventure key items. Why am I given the choice to pick it up or not if I need it to progress? Seems strange. What do my choices even mean?\n\nSo I get to the end

reviewText: A very simple game that i do not feel was worth the cash. Reminds mw of old adventure games we use to program back in school.

Home

+ Charming Retro 8bit graphics and gameplay
+ Minimalist style aided by descriptive text feedback

- Plot is essentially wide open and unsatisfying
- Weak script with references to things the player never did or saw
- Choices are apparently meaningless
- Very short (around 1 hour)
- Very little replay value

OK for 50p and an hour to waste but not worth £1.

Conclusion: 5/10. Meh.

This is the sort of game that wants you to wear head phones and play in the dark. Yet after about half an hour I was no longer scared, just bored.

Now, I like games with stories and so I really want to like this game but the plot is just...

[SPOILERS AHEAD. SPOILERS!]

I appreciated that you get to kind of pick your ending, in the way that I appreciate it almost any time a game gives me a decision, but since it wasn't as free roaming as I would have liked (I can't solve a mystery until I realize there is a mystery game) and the fact that I was continually nudged along, the huge plot twist being up to me made the game feel... pointless?

Like, if I wanted to write another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ psychological horror about an insane alcoholic I could have done this myself.

I think the game would have been vastly more interesting to me if it weren't just another white man with problems who is trying to rescue a woman (plot twist being either that he killed her or she was made up in his head wooo boy wow such twist much psychological).

It's a stupid cheap game, so I guess I recommend it if you really like stories about white men gaining agency.

But otherwise, even at this price? You can pass.

[WARNING] This review is basically a breakdown of my playthrough/experience of this game. Therefore, it's pretty lengthy and contains spoilers, but it's worth a read if you don't mind the amount of reading, I'm sure a good portion of people who have played this game already can relate to what's written below.

After sitting untouched in my Steam Library for awhile, tonight I finally decided to give it a go. I wasn't really sure what to expect, but with lights out and headphones in, I booted the game up and began playing.

As I wandered about the starting house, I already became pretty interested in the premise. Exploring your mysterious surroundings in search of clues in order to piece together a dark narrative brimming with secrecy and murder seemed right up my alley. I made sure to search every room, check things multiple times so I didn't miss a helpful piece of dialogue, and made sure I picked up anything I came across in case I needed it later. I couldn't wait to begin unraveling this story.

Then, I left the house, and appropriately ended up in the sewers.

From then on, the game started to fall apart for me. Once the character started dropping comments about the handgun and knife I picked up as I searched through the tunnels and sewers, it was pretty easy to figure out what was really going on. But I brushed those thoughts aside and pressed on hoping that something ahead would add a new piece to the puzzle that would make me completely rethink my theories up to this point.

Then, after completing a few more areas, the tedium began to set in. I was disappointed with the lack of complexity, the only puzzles being turning a valve a few times until they opened or navigating a maze" of pathways to find more clues. At this point the main character has already beaten the fact that everything seems oddly familiar over my head too many times for me to really question anything about the story anymore
date: which made me wonder why I was even bothering trying to find all of these different pieces of evidence. But there was one major problem I had that seemed to keep reoccurring throughout my playthrough:\n\nThe game faltered between rewarding and punishing you for exploring. reviewText:
Pop quiz! Let's start! 1. Do you like Indie games? 2. Do you like horror/thriller games? 3. Do you like to spend you time doing things that make you happy? Well if you answered yes to any of those questions then turn yourself back around right now and walk away!

Now I want to get this across, Home is not a terrible game if you're not expecting too much. It just failed to be a good game in many ways!

Now the start of Home is quite promising and you find yourself to be a little scared while you're walking around the underground pipeline. As you delve deeper into the suspense of this spooky" dungeon you'll finally find a door after breaking your leg and finding other misc. items which have absolutely nothing to do with the outcome of the game! You finally get an eerie chill once you finally get to the surface where you'll find yourself in an abyssal forest with your belongings on the corpses of random dead people (spooky). date: you'll climb up the tower and peer off the balcony at the top
recommended: and as you hear your character say "It feels as if someone's watching me" you can kiss good-bye to any scare value this game had to offer because it ends here. The rest of the game you just wander back to your house and find your dead wife to only find out that you're a murderer who killed her

voteText: like everything else in this game nothing has an impact especially when the ending depends on what you choose. They just make you decide after the 50 minutes of gameplay how to finish the game. After having to come to a conclusion on whether what you should do you begin to feel cheated. I'm pretty sure I payed $5 for this game at the time I bought it and boy do I regret it. reviewText:
Not a bad game.

It was a great concept with less than satisfying execution. This is a horror game that is designed with some very good elements of level design, music, art style, and atmosphere.
However, the game at it's core is just a simplified point-and-click adventure.

**SPOILERS**

There is no true element of danger in any of part of the game. The only thing that possibly serves to hinder your progress are one-way doors that progress you through chapters(for lack of a better term). There are many optional clues to be found which keeps the player engaged and motivated to search everywhere. However, the ultimate downfall of the game is that NONE OF IT REALLY MATTERS.
The ending of the game literally asks you to determine what happens at the end. Depending on your choices, the game retcons details and clues and the layout of your house in order to conform (mostly) to the conclusion you draw. But inconsistencies still exist, and no matter what permutation of choices you make, it still doesn't deliver a compelling or conclusive story.
This game would be salvageable if the clues you found determined the ending rather than asking you to do it. It's an interesting experiment in storytelling to involve the reader in choosing the story path rather than the actions that should determine the story path... but in my opinion it is extremely unsatisfying. Please abandon this line of thinking and tell a story through the actions of the character you're attaching the player to rather than asking the player directly for input.

A cute little 8-bit psychological thriller that anyone can appreciate. As a suggestion... play it at night with the lights off and your earphones plugged in, and feast on the creaks and ghoulish sounds that make the game just that more gratifying.

In terms of gameplay and player interaction, this game is quite minimal. This is most certainly an interactive story, and you should take the advice of waiting til dark, shutting off the lights, and playing for a little over an hour, just to beat it. It adds a lot to do it in one sitting. For the three dollar asking price, I most certainly recommend Home.

This game is horrible. You realize what happened about a third of the way through the game, and the rest is just walking around doing useless tedious tasks. I honestly wanted to bash my monitor in halfway through it. Sure, it's an interesting and sad story, but it's just not a good game.

This is the sort of game that wants you to wear head phones and play in the dark. Yet after about half an hour I was no longer scared, just bored.

Now, I like games with stories and so I really want to like this game but the plot is just...

[SPOILERS AHEAD. SPOILERS!]

I appreciated that you get to kind of pick your ending, in the way that I appreciate it almost any time a game gives me a decision, but since it wasn't as free roaming as I would have liked (I can't solve a mystery until I realize there is a mystery game) and the fact that I was continually nudged along, the huge plot twist being up to me made the game feel... pointless?

Like, if I wanted to write another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ psychological horror about an insane alcoholic I could have done this myself.

I think the game would have been vastly more interesting to me if it weren't just another white man with problems who is trying to rescue a woman (plot twist being either that he killed her or she was made up in his head wooo boy wow such twist much psychological).

It's a stupid cheap game, so I guess I recommend it if you really like stories about white men gaining agency.

But otherwise, even at this price? You can pass.

[WARNING] This review is basically a breakdown of my playthrough/experience of this game. Therefore, it's pretty lengthy and contains spoilers, but it's worth a read if you don't mind the amount of reading, I'm sure a good portion of people who have played this game already can relate to what's written below.

After sitting untouched in my Steam Library for awhile, tonight I finally decided to give it a go. I wasn't really sure what to expect, but with lights out and headphones in, I booted the game up and began playing.

As I wandered about the starting house, I already became pretty interested in the premise. Exploring your mysterious surroundings in search of clues in order to piece together a dark narrative brimming with secrecy and murder seemed right up my alley. I made sure to search every room, check things multiple times so I didn't miss a helpful piece of dialogue, and made sure I picked up anything I came across in case I needed it later. I couldn't wait to begin unraveling this story.

Then, I left the house, and appropriately ended up in the sewers.

From then on, the game started to fall apart for me. Once the character started dropping comments about the handgun and knife I picked up as I searched through the tunnels and sewers, it was pretty easy to figure out what was really going on. But I brushed those thoughts aside and pressed on hoping that something ahead would add a new piece to the puzzle that would make me completely rethink my theories up to this point.

Then, after completing a few more areas, the tedium began to set in. I was disappointed with the lack of complexity, the only puzzles being turning a valve a few times until they opened or navigating a maze" of pathways to find more clues. At this point the main character has already beaten the fact that everything seems oddly familiar over my head too many times for me to really question anything about the story anymore
date: which made me wonder why I was even bothering trying to find all of these different pieces of evidence. But there was one major problem I had that seemed to keep reoccurring throughout my playthrough:\n\nThe game faltered between rewarding and punishing you for exploring. reviewText: Prety nice little experiment in atmospheric horror through sinister imagery and narrative. I enjoy this style of horror way more than anything FNAF or any other big-name jumpscare horror games bring. I'll give it a worthy 10/10. Solid spooky atmosphere in a place you don't know anything about and while the pacing of the game isn't very quick, its slowness complements the game's atmosphere perfectly. Overall a great little indie game that's infinitely worth the $3.

This title is an absolute joy. I played and completed this game back a couple years ago but just recently played and beat it again. It's a great story. It's not for those who don't like slow games or games where you just basically walk around and investigate. Choices don't seem to matter but I've only played through twice. This game is very short, about an hour and a half. At the begginning of the game it tells you it's best to have headphones on and an hour and a half of free time to finish it in one sitting to get the full effect. This I absolutely recommend doing. With this game a lot is left up the the imagination of the player which I love but many people who need hand holding or have never enjoyed a good cliffhanger in a book do not appreciate. It is a great game for what it is and it has psychological elements although very subtle. The story feels slow but in fact isn't. The game itself is 1 1/2 hours. Depending on how you play and if you're a completionist or have to explore everything the pacing is basically based on how you play. I enjoyed this title and highly recommend. I mean, come on, $3 bucks. It's great.
Took me 49 minutes to complete, the game's ambient was okay, but the play had nothing to offer, I picked up firearms and never used them, since I not came a cross any monsters at all! 2/10

TL;DR: Home is a valiant one man effort that fails to convey the sense of horror needed to call it a horror game.

I have somewhat of a soft spot for one man games. I am assuming this was done by one man, as the whole created by Benjamin Rivers thing does too. And this is fairly impressive for one man, so props to him. However, just because one man made it, it is not automatically awesome. Does Home stand as a good example of a indie horror game?

So, Home. Critical praise all-round.  Disliked by many players. Why? Because the game is simply dull. It is not very scary in the traditional sense. No real gore, no jump scares. So very un-American horror movie. The horror on display here is psychological, and real, but weak. It takes the Silent Hill approach of giving you a room full of alluded to knowledge and asking that your mind takes it from there. I would say it is fairly unsettling, but considering that I was playing a bombastic loud-n-proud zombie game (Dying Light) about 3 hours earlier, in a dark room with some gore and alluded to happenings and was significantly more on edge, Home could be doing a bit better in this department.

The point I am trying to get across here is that Home on the surface makes a good bone-chilling horror experience, but fails to deliver.

Home contains some light adventure game elements, but they actively conflict with the plot. In order reveal secrets or in some cases progress the game, one must find items strewn about the current portion of the map being explored, however the point of the game is to get to your titular home, and exploring to find items to unlock more information is illogical considering that.

To surmise. Home seems alright on the store page, but in all reality it just can’t hold up. I have a general philosophy that a game should deliver 1 hour of entertainment per $2 spent of it, and home has provided me with 1 hour of mediocre entertainment for $3. I don’t plan on replaying the game, and I would only recommend this if it goes on sale for 1 dollar or less.

4/10
Would not recommend
Don’t bother

So be a man, pick it up, maybe even gift it to the wife as an anniversary present. She might like it.

Okay, I'm going to give this game a reccomended thumbs up HOWEVER! It just barely does it for me.

Spoilers!!! Maybe? Beware nonetheless

While I didn't really find this game to be the horror-esque it claimed to be, I did find it was a nice quick play through that involved some exploration and a classic, choose your own adventure style.

I had some trepedation at first, as always with games that claim to be horrors, wondering what kind of jump scares awaited me on the other side. Home offered no jump scares really... and as I played I found out my character, though he came across death multiple times, had no possible way of dying... so that was a disappointment at first... and although it let me take my time and start to explore a bit... it actually took away from the whole feel of it in the end.

I went about exploring the first area entirely, the house with the dead man, trying to find what I could. I took some papers, left the gun... and found a video which I never really got to see the outcome of... I missed a point in the home where I could've viewed it I guess... but as the game progressed I found myself enjoying the exploration and the possibility of finding more clues as to why your character awoke where he did.

The time flew by and before I knew it I was at the end. It was a very short game though but having bought it on sale for 75 cents I really can't complain.

By the end I got to choose how I interpreted the clues I had stumbled upon, kicked myself for missing a few pieces of the story and found myself kinda, just a little bit... wanting to play it one more time just to see what kind of ending I could get the second round. However I have still yet to play it again and unless the mood really really REALLY strikes me to, I most likely won't.

So, with that said...

Story: 7/10

I enjoyed it as I started to get into the game. I liked the choose your own adventure style of it and the whole mystery aspect. However I was very disappointed with the horror aspect the synopsis claimed this game to have. It left much to be desired.

Replay Value: 5/10

I might replay the game once more to figure out what I missed and what else I can get, but as for that I think this game would be retired from my shelf.

Graphics: 5/10

Wasn't much of a fan of the choice of graphics this time round. While the developer did a good job overall with his choice... I felt the game could've used more detail that doesn't come with the old pixel-style graphics. It left much to be desired.

(Sale)Value: 6/10

I mentioned I had bought this for 0.75 and I found that to be worth it. It gave me enough entertainment for the time the game lasted.

(Full) Value: 1.5/10

I wouldn't have bought this game had it been the full 2.99. Granted its only three bucks but seriously... I've seen much much MUCH better games go on sale on Steam for 5 bucks... and that 3 bucks would've been better invested towards those games.

Ambiance/Music: 8/10

This is what helped the game move along for me. Ambiance alone can help make or break a game so I applaude the developer in this aspect.

Overall... out of 10... I would give this game a 5.5/10 good for the quick hour or two you may play it, but then shelf dust after that.

HOME is the story of man awaking alone in a house, not knowing how he got there and what happened.
While trying to recover his memory he encounters strange places where some horrible things have happened.
The story gradually unfolds by the choices you make which frees up some different insights he might have about the events you encounter. It's up to you how he remembers his life, what happened, why and how and what he did or not did and how it ends altogether when he finally reaches his home . . .

Great suggestive atmosphere and a story that has an ending depending on the the choices/actions you made.

Creepy, definitely makes you wonder, and trying to figure out what is going on is just as fun as exploring and trying to find your way out. Don't play this expecting a big challenge - that's not the point. It's an experience" game that didn't forget to be fun and interesting."

I thoroughly enjoy the freedom this game gives you. Although short, it is entirely packed with atmosphere and it makes you really think about what is going on. I love that you decide the ending, and each one is just a bit more unsettling than the last.

Once the character started dropping comments about the handgun and knife I picked up as I searched through the tunnels and sewers, it was pretty easy to figure out what was really going on. But I brushed those thoughts aside and pressed on hoping that something ahead would add a new piece to the puzzle that would make me completely rethink my theories up to this point.

Then, after completing a few more areas, the tedium began to set in. I was disappointed with the lack of complexity, the only puzzles being turning a valve a few times until they opened or navigating a maze" of pathways to find more clues. At this point the main character has already beaten the fact that everything seems oddly familiar over my head too many times for me to really question anything about the story anymore

HOME is a fantastic psychological horror game at a fantastic price. It deserves to be bought and played. It can suffer from too much ambiguity in some playthroughs depending the options that are presented and your related choices. Each playthrough is meant to provide a unique experience.

HOME is a game where everything clicks for its genre. The setting works, the sound is right, the graphics are done well. The right atmosphere is created.

If you like psychological horror and are interested in the randomly generated story experience creating a unique playthrough each time then HOME is a game you should play.

The story is good but its something you have to put together as you go the game is not going to set you on one path of story and tell you everything thats going on. An interesting game. The entire plot is based on your character remembering what happened. This is interesting because there is actually what happened and what you tell yourself. The description will tell you that you shape the story but this is not totally true. You shape your perspective but the game makes it fairly clear what actually happens, whether you allow yourself to believe it or not. I did not think it was particularly scary so if your new to the horror genre this is a good starter. I would not say its a replayable game, at least not for me, because it was very wordy, especially towards the end. This is not a problem at first, but after an hour and your getting to the end where, in most games, there is action to keep you interested, instead there is more text than usual. It doesnt take long to play at all, in the beggining it estimates 1.5 hours and I was pretty close to that time. How long it takes really depends on how much you explore. In the beginning you can pretty much explore everything no problem, but in the middle there is a lot more available that you may or may not choose to ignore.

This a strange game that isn't scary buy feels real. Its atmosphere is fantastic and its story is well thought out with many different ways to see things. It isn’t your typical horror game but it’s not trying to be at all. It’s just a good 2D adventure that makes you think about what is going on. It’s only 1 hour long but for the price it is asking that is ok with me. Just try it and see why games are best when they are close to home.

Home isn't really a game in the classic sense, in much the same vein as Gone Home or Dear Esther. You walk around, you find things, you figure out the plot of the game after the fact.  Home's major twist is that your decision to pick things up, push things around, go through or ignore certain doors, ultimately decides what that overall narrative is.

If that kinda gameplay isn't your thing, of course you're going to hate it. As long as you know what the general idea is going in, I don't think you'll be too disappointed.  In a way, I kind of love the game not so much for its storytelling as its dependence on community-interpretation.  On their website, you can see everyone's analysis of what they thought was going on.

In some small way, it goes straight back to the Lovecraftian base fear of the unknown.  There are no exact answers, only an attempt to put together the pieces that are there.  I'm pretty sure there are no happy endings here, just a terrible situation.  I'm gonna do some more diving on another day, try and get the most benevolent ending I can, but I'm not sure such a thing is possible.

There are two or three jump scares, but as is always the case, the true monster is MAN

The closest I've aver seen a videogame replicate the thing that makes the tabletop games so special. Here's a tip/example: going some side direction or not going, even looking or investigation something or just walking by changes the way the story goes. Another, but just a tip: set aside a movie length of time and play through it in one go. A final one, but just an example rather then a tip: you get to tell the game what you think it all means.

You ultimately decide how the story plays out, and you can't save (which is a cool thing) so you HAVE to play it through to the end (around 1-2 hours tops).  High replay value if just to find out the other ending possibilities.

This game may not be the scariest Indie-Horror I've played, but don't let that keep you aaway. It has one of the most interesting and engrossing stories I've ever experienced in an Indie. Home is a very unique horror/adventure game where you control a very skeptical man who wakes up in an old house, failing to remember anything that has happened before. It is your job to get him home (hence the name) and find out what the hell caused all of this, finding out a few shocking secrets along the way. The best part? YOU get to decide how it ends!

Personally, I really enjoy this game, and I have no idea why it receives so much hate. It is one of my favorite games in the horror/suspense genre, as it has kept me in suspense quite a few times. The only downside is that the game is rather short.

If you like horror games, Home is definitely worth a look-see.

This game is like a very strange piece of poetry. Not everybody will like it, find it to their tastes. Some might love it.
Entire game is about dugging fingers into a dead corpse without any anatomical knowledge and trying to figure out what part is responsible for in this bloody mess. After some tries things can get messy but everybody will figure out some things, one way or another. Depending which trail of guts you'll choose, you'll find different things but in the end something will be revealed in front of you.
I, personally, have mixed feelings about this game. Atmosphere is great, pixel art more often fits than not and overall idea is amazing... But. But. Sometimes there are some visual changes underlined in text without any reflection to the reality of the game, which breaks description into soemthing of little importance. Also sometimes text can get very specific about certain things without any reason whatsoever so one has to scroll throught tiny walls of text. Watching animations of opened doors, of passing from one are to the other can get tedious after few minutes.
All in all, not bad, could be better, applause for idea, a little bit of 'boo' for some stuff.

reviewText: Absolutely loved this game. Played it twice through back to back in order to see a different ending. It's a Choose Your Own Adventure book as a game, except with dead bodies and super creepy sound effects. Give it a play!
Really creepy. Difficult to understand what really happened, and that's the thrill ! Just read other's player experience gives chills...

Very short, and I couldn't wait for it to be over.  Disappointed in this one, I just didn't get it at all.

This shouldn't be called horror, and that's its biggest mistake, if you ask me.

For many, I suspect, horror involves more explicit terrifying elements than corpses and the shifting sounds of buildings. In this respect, this game is far more of a psychological thriller than it is a horror game. Perhaps, it might be said, this is one of the very few thriller titles to be found in games, since it makes the decision to exclude both combat and any direct enemy confrontations. As other reviews indicate, despite mentioning that you choose the ending, the absence of any indication of whether you truly confront the cause of all the events led them to disappointment.

However, while I can understand this perspective, I think that the game stands up well enough on its own, with the interesting use of interaction with objects influencing the narrative, to get by with this. In fact, the very real recognition of your presence at certain points makes this an especially interesting title to me, whereas for others it seemed a copout. It wasn't the most graceful integration of the player's involvement, admittedly, but it was closer in tune to what I had hoped Deadly Premonition would do, if familiar with that title.

Either way, for as cheap and short as it is, and for what seems to me very decent quality (sound design/writing/artistically), I'd say this title is a steal if you're interested in games that experiment with interactive narratives.

I found this game to be unsatisfying. I am completely for player choice in games and I can see what this game was trying to do, points for trying. But I felt I had no guidance to ensure a coherent narrative. By the end of the choice section, the story summary I received was nonsensical and ridiculous. Otherwise, I thought the game was okay. Good looking game, good sound, plays smoothly. The atmosphere started out creepy, but I quickly got accustomed and the game made no attempt to intensify things. For most of my playthrough I was bored and then I finished up as very confused. It's only about an hour long.

reviewText: It's basically a narrative game you interact with every single object.\nThe game is so linear, it's boring.

You wake up in a strange room and find a few dead bodies. Bad thing is, you can't remember anything and the murderer could still be around. Well... not really... I think at this point it is clear that you are the murderer. But okay, let's pretend we don't know. You start waaaaaaalking from room to room just to discover more dead bodies and personal items of your own. A lot of personal items... It's like you walked through your house the night before, filled up a big bag of random stuff and spread it all around town afterwards. And now you've got to pick all the stuff back up. At the end your character is drawing some conclusions probably based on the stuff you've picked up ealier. And THAT IS ALL.

1. Walk around.
2. Pick up any random item. (Confirm the hell out of your Y-Botton)
3. Get confronted with dead bodies and names you have never heard of.
4. Repeat.

Boring as hell. Almost at the end of the game, you are confronted with the first real riddle. It's a safe and you are literally getting no hints whatsoever how to unlock the damn thing. Frustrated, I looked the combination up on google and you know what? You really don't get any hint, it's just written into the game's manual. Btw it's 4R3UHER3

My very first review. English is not my native language. Potato.

Home isn't really a game in the classic sense, in much the same vein as Gone Home or Dear Esther. You walk around, you find things, you figure out the plot of the game after the fact.  Home's major twist is that your decision to pick things up, push things around, go through or ignore certain doors, ultimately decides what that overall narrative is.

If that kinda gameplay isn't your thing, of course you're going to hate it. As long as you know what the general idea is going in, I don't think you'll be too disappointed.  In a way, I kind of love the game not so much for its storytelling as its dependence on community-interpretation.  On their website, you can see everyone's analysis of what they thought was going on.

In some small way, it goes straight back to the Lovecraftian base fear of the unknown.  There are no exact answers, only an attempt to put together the pieces that are there.  I'm pretty sure there are no happy endings here, just a terrible situation.  I'm gonna do some more diving on another day, try and get the most benevolent ending I can, but I'm not sure such a thing is possible.

There are two or three jump scares, but as is always the case, the true monster is MAN

Gra jest horrorowka ale niema w niej potworow jedynym wrogiem jest psychika bohatera.... polecam gierke kupilem ja za 0.99 Euro i byly to dobrze wydane centy :P

If you're a fan of the kind of madness that's the hallmark of Lovecraftian stories then Home is right up your alley."

reviewText:
Home is a very unique horror/adventure game where you control a very skeptical man who wakes up in an old house, failing to remember anything that has happened before. It is your job to get him home (hence the name) and find out what the hell caused all of this, finding out a few shocking secrets along the way. The best part? YOU get to decide how it ends!

Personally, I really enjoy this game, and I have no idea why it receives so much hate. It is one of my favorite games in the horror/suspense genre, as it has kept me in suspense quite a few times. The only downside is that the game is rather short.

If you like horror games, Home is definitely worth a look-see.
Extremamente repetitivo e sem imaginação.

Pop quiz! Let's start! 1. Do you like Indie games? 2. Do you like horror/thriller games? 3. Do you like to spend you time doing things that make you happy? Well if you answered yes to any of those questions then turn yourself back around right now and walk away!

Now I want to get this across, Home is not a terrible game if you're not expecting too much. It just failed to be a good game in many ways!

Now the start of Home is quite promising and you find yourself to be a little scared while you're walking around the underground pipeline. As you delve deeper into the suspense of this spooky" dungeon you'll finally find a door after breaking your leg and finding other misc. items which have absolutely nothing to do with the outcome of the game! You finally get an eerie chill once you finally get to the surface where you'll find yourself in an abyssal forest with your belongings on the corpses of random dead people (spooky). Then there's the tower
date: you'll climb up the tower and peer off the balcony at the top
recommended: and as you hear your character say "It feels as if someone's watching me" you can kiss good-bye to any scare value this game had to offer because it ends here. The rest of the game you just wander back to your house and find your dead wife to only find out that you're a murderer who killed her
hoursPlayed: and well every other poor soul you saw in the past 20 minutes. Then you'll get the suspenseful choice between killing yourself or just walking out the door. Now after all the non-existent character developement you'll find it so difficult to decide! Because
voteText: like everything else in this game nothing has an impact especially when the ending depends on what you choose. They just make you decide after the 50 minutes of gameplay how to finish the game. After having to come to a conclusion on whether what you should do you begin to feel cheated. I'm pretty sure I payed $5 for this game at the time I bought it and boy do I regret it. This game lacks any amount of good gameplay and fulfillment which is exactly where it lacks from beginning to the end! Now where this game can go right is if you're looking for a retro styled game that can bring back memories. The design of the world makes you feel relaxed and calm which the horror factor can pull away from. Now lets face it

reviewText:
Home

+ Charming Retro 8bit graphics and gameplay
+ Minimalist style aided by descriptive text feedback

- Plot is essentially wide open and unsatisfying
- Weak script with references to things the player never did or saw
- Choices are apparently meaningless
- Very short (around 1 hour)
- Very little replay value

OK for 50p and an hour to waste but not worth £1.

Conclusion: 5/10. Meh.

Very Deep and thought provoking game. Theres a lot of text and little action so its not for most, but it certainly takes a new twist on the way these games tend to work. Less of a horror, more of a thriller.

A very interesting narrative concept. There isn't much to it gameplay-wise, not even the cannonic puzzles which you would expect, but this game is a good tension builder and the way it makes you shape your story is definitely worth a check.

Pros:
+originality in concept and design
+interesting story
+A LOT of significant narrative choices

Cons:
-not much actual gameplay involved
-might seem a bit repeatitive at times, especially considering the graphics
-some of the narrative isn't written very well

Conclusion: Definitely a unique and worth-checking game!

A very short game/story, where you wake up with memory loss and a murder has taken place. Not exactly the most original story.

You then walk around the environments, learning stuff and deciding what has happened. At the end you can share your story and learn other people’s perspective of the story. Sound is used well. The text is interesting to read.

I didn't get much out of the experience. It’s an unclear and meaingless story where the story makes pretty much every possibility possible. This is my least favourite type of story, because for me it feels lazy and incomplete.
The best way to describe this game is a choose your own adventure" visual novel that doesn't have any dead ends
date: but rather has different endings at the very end of the game based on what you picked up (or didn't pick up)."

reviewText:
(Warning: I discuss spoilers. Play the game first if you're interested,  it takes 90 minutes.)

My approach to this game was wrong.

I had a restless night to kill, I had only my Macbook, and needed something graphics-lite I could play with my keyboard. Home seemed like the perfect fit.

It seemed set up as an adventure game with an easy interface. Great! I found myself quickly analyzing clues, trying to piece together what was happening. That being said, the game doesn't challenge you to *actually* understand much of anything - and so my character's frequent questions about what he was looking at just fed the sense of mystery.

I was expecting answers. That's not a good start.

The atmosphere is generally unsettling because the game teaches you very early on that the game's volume is on 5 and the game's audio jump scares are on THIRTY MOTHER♥♥♥♥ING TWO. I turned down the whole thing and ruined the atmosphere just to save myself a heart attack. But it's a cheap parlor trick - nothing ever comes out of the shadows, it's just noises.

There are many choices you can make. Do I pick up the bloody knife or leave it? Well, I seemed to be an amnesiac in an unknown environment with dead bodies everywhere, so yeah, I'll take the knife. I'd hate for something else to take the knife and kill me with it. My character then muses, Did I really need this knife?" ..... Well now wait a minute
date: I thought I was being practical. Am I just being paranoid? Does the game think I'm a violent person now?\n\nI picked up the knife
hoursPlayed: I picked up most objects that seemed useful. And some objects I decided seemed pointless wound up being typical adventure key items. Why am I given the choice to pick it up or not if I need it to progress? Seems strange. What do my choices even mean?\n\nSo I get to the end
voteText: ready for the story to come together. The game asks me if I find my wife. For some intuitive reason
helpfulPercent: I just don't get the feeling I do. So I answer no. I'm comfortable with that choice. But then the game asks me another 15 questions about the items I've collected and everything else that is going on. Well I mean
votesHelpful: I'm not sure
votesTotal: I've only been playing for an hour. Is there a right or wrong answer? If I'm not sure
votesFunny: do I really have to pick yes or no?\n\nI didn't have any solid understanding of what was happening throughout what I was experiencing
commentsCount: and I'm sure most people would agree with that - it's designed that way. So why then is the game quizzing you on this understanding at the end of the game? I never answered yes or no - I only answered
column16: "Um...yes?" or "Grrr
column17: pff
column18: I dunno
column19: no?" It would take a clearer narrative to expect any clearer reaction
column20: wouldn't it?\n\nI mean
column21: what arrogant self-assured idiot would go through an obtuse series of unrelated mysteries and think
column23: I know EXACTLY what's going on here"? There literally is no right answer
column24: so attempting to decide what your choices meant within a meaningless context is itself an utterly meaningless action.\n\nAnd of course

reviewText:
Home is a short and story rich game. The main character wakes up with seemingly no memories.

The player's job is to explore and find clues about what's happened. There's some replay value, if you want to try leaving behind an item you picked up the first time or if you managed to miss an area or a room. There are some statements the game wants the player to confirm or deny at the end to summarize the story. Although as far as I know the story is up to interpretation.

To me this was decent fun for 2 hours (played through it twice) and I recommend the game if you want to try solving a mystery
Boring and lacks a coherent ending. its more about the horror experience of a character with amnesia who finds his dead coworker and wife.

I received this game as a gift from another friend a while ago.  I never finished it the first time and I've switched computers since then, but I came back to Steam and decided to redownload it and give it a play.  This game has a very rich, complex story, and some events within it are obvious, while the rest of it leaves you to ponder.  I like the interaction you get within the game and your impending sense of aloneness."  It makes for a spooky game you can get immersed into.  The sound effects are subtle
date: but creepy.  I think they work well with the pixel graphics
recommended: and a few of the noises legitimately made me jump (I'm easy to scare when I'm engrossed in these kinds of games
hoursPlayed: so it probably won't scare most other people.)  The game isn't a jump scare game like you might think or expect
voteText: though.  The story is what keeps you up thinking at night.\n\nMy only complaint with this game
helpfulPercent: is that you don't get true closure in the end after you have supposedly "solved the mystery."  It leaves the ending open and squirming in your own mind.  I think some aspects are painfully obvious (i.e. the character had something to do with the killings in his temporary mental state
votesHelpful: which he talks about.)  Some
votesTotal: on the other hand
votesFunny: don't give you full closure.  Why was he in the strange house?  (aside from it being necessary for the plot)  Who was the other man who had "killed his wife" and why was it important?  How long was the character unaware of the time frame in which all these events happened and he began to backtrack once he was awake?  Etc.
commentsCount: etc.\n\nThe game is great if you're looking for story driven.  It has an Amnesia feel to it in terms of the mystery of "what happened" although it might not have the solid answers you might be looking for in the end.  However
column16: I do think the players who enjoy this will enjoy the overall mystery of the game as well as the mystery when the game is finished.  It's worth the one sitting play-through (which they do recommend you set time aside at the beginning to do.)"

Keeping with the happy reviews as another indie game I have played, has not dissapointed. Home is a short, pixelated, side scrolling horror game, which is based heavily on reading and exploration. Given the details mentioned this game is surely not for everyone, but putting that aside, why is it good?

Home is a very atmospheric game, giving players just ambience to listen to throughout the 1 hour long experience (I use this word instead of game on purpose), the story follows a man who has woken up in a strange, unkown place, and is set the main obkective of returning home, to find his wife. As you get closer to home the story delves deeper and more questions arise, finding strange objects and horrifying scenarios, but maintaining zero jump scares.

Home was enjoyable to play, being a game I could start and finish in one sitting, but as stated earlier there is no really exciting gameplay, but more of a filmic experience. I give Home 6/10

This one is thought provoking. For me, it is not a game... Its a story, and a decently told one at that. Theres no real challenge element involved in the point-and-click style play. [Home] feels like it wants to be a story more than a game. It claims to be a horror, but although chilling in places, i'd not call it horror. I was expecting 'scarey' and only got 'eerie'. That said. I think I liked it. Well for 47p I couldn't really be disappointed, could I? The game leaves you to decide the story's ending but the plot is so full of holes and open questions, you'll never be fully satisfied. None the less, it'll stay in my thoughts for quite some time. Very thought proviking...
Very unique horror game that keeps you  thinking and on edge.
