reviewText:
So...do I recommend it....depends on what you expect.

It sure as hell is no Silent Hill
(which I played the first time alone in a hut in the woods on a b&w screen - scared sh.tless 20/10).

The fun in this game, me thinks, is to play it over and over again with every instance adding to the mystery (not exact horror) and making you think what could have happened to whom and why and in what order.

I´ve only been through one time so far (65 minutes) and came up with a rather obvious conclusion which leaves a lot of odds and ends open. It certainly makes you think if you are able to immerse and identify yourself with the protagonist - or is he an antagonist? Find out for yourself :)

It is not really scary due to the low resolution and at first glance I was pretty sure to get to see some mad scientists´ lab and an Edsel too (those who played the game I´m speaking of will know, others just don´t - haha).

So, if you´re looking for some snack inbetween other games, give it a try and do not spoiler yourself.

I´ll give it 6 out of 10 points - one point had to be taken due to really low-res graphics and anotherone for not being able to save at all but it doesn´t take ages to get to the end.

Not much to talk about, the game is short and leaves a lot to interpretation, you can play it multiple times to gather more information on what happened but that´s about it, it seems there are 2 endings I wont spoil, but what really makes the game cool is interpreting what might have happened after the ending and sharing it on social media or read other people experiences (the game sends you there after finishing).

You could say there is no real ending, just points of view and your descision making towards the end.

I recomend it because is interesting enough for the low price (imo), but if you dont like narrative stories stay away from this one.

Home was a very intense game for being so simple! I would advise playing in the dark with headphones for full effects.
I will say that some of the sounds (certain doors) were very loud when they squeak open, so be aware of that!
Suspense was amazing all the way through, expect everything! Music helped the atmosphere a ton!

I only played one playthrough for one ending (yep, multiple endings!) and it was enjoyable. However I don't feel any compelling urge to play again for other endings (and not for the suspense). Other than that, its a well made game.
I see people say You need imagination to enjoy this game". ♥♥♥♥ that

This is an attempt at video game art that could've been great, but ultimately failed in execution. The whole experience builds up to something - and then there is no real finale, no climax, no point d'orgue.\nI do not recommend this game, because you will be disappointed. Instead, let's wait for Benjamin Rivers' next project. He has proven to be capable of producing great games, I hope he will produce a completed and self-contained experience with his next game.

This game is just a waste of time. It runs at a resolution that is actually LOWER than a gameboy colour's (which is a frightening trend) and the sounds are just regular bleep bloops, nothing special there, but w/e I didn't play it for graphics.

Basically, you walk around. Home is pretty much a 2D walking simulator. While you walk, you come across random ♥♥♥♥, and you say either yes or no and things slightly change. It sounds spooky , right? You get a slightly different ending eventually depending on your choices. And at the end, the writer flexes his muscles and breaks the fourth wall, citing choices you've made. That's the most impact your choices will make - the entire game WILL play the same regardless of what you do, and choices are ultimately a gimmick to attract sales or whatever.

It's supposed to be a horror game, but the feeling that you're being stalked wears off after oh, I dunno, the first 20 minutes of hearing impromptu noises but never seeing anything that threatens you. By the way, nothing threatens you. Home puts in a good effort to build in an atmosphere, but when there's nothing threatening you there is just literally nothing to be afraid of. I'm a horror game ♥♥♥♥♥ and I went through this without blinking!

One thing the game does well: it invests you in the game to a certain point. Lack of horror aside, the game drip-feeds you with clues as to the backstory, and I often found my own mind whirring, thinking and generating my own theories as to what happened. This is truly one of the few times a game has done this right for me, so bravo. Unfortunately, the ending is just so subpar. I'm not gonna spoil anything because there is literally nothign to spoil - basically, it just confirms everything that already happened and ends. This wouldn't be bad, except all you have at this point are your theories, and the game doesn't confirm ANY of them! You're left with more questions than answers - and it's alluded you'll learn more with another playthrough with different choices. Don't waste your time...

Stay away, save your two bucks. I enjoyed the way the game kept me invested, but it really doesn't hold that appeal and every other aspect of the game just falls flat.

it's a very chill game but it was not scary at all even though you may hear strange noises. You mostly just wander around the game finding clues and interacting with objects but yeah... Was not my thing, I was hoping for a little more, even the story was not that entertaining for me...

Home is what Dear Ester should have been, a dynamic narrative that can subtly change for each player. Unlike Dear Ester, Home is engaging. The closer you get to the end, the more tension builds in the game and in your own head, and your experience comes closer to mirroring that of the character you play. In Home, atmosphere is the star and it gets so thick you can cut it with a knife. It's one of the few horror games that really filled me with a sense of dread and unease as I moved cloister to the end. I had two issues, you can't save and one flawed puzzle at the end. The game is an hour or so long so I had to abandon my first attempt at about 30min in. One of the final puzzles requires an alt+tab out of the game to play an ARG or just google the answer, breaking the experience either way. Overall an excellent experience, double so given the low price of admission. Also, the developer seems cool, he answered my question about a mac version on twitter :P

Prety nice little experiment in atmospheric horror through sinister imagery and narrative. I enjoy this style of horror way more than anything FNAF or any other big-name jumpscare horror games bring. I'll give it a worthy 10/10. Solid spooky atmosphere in a place you don't know anything about and while the pacing of the game isn't very quick, its slowness complements the game's atmosphere perfectly. Overall a great little indie game that's infinitely worth the $3.

This title is an absolute joy. I played and completed this game back a couple years ago but just recently played and beat it again. It's a great story. It's not for those who don't like slow games or games where you just basically walk around and investigate. Choices don't seem to matter but I've only played through twice. This game is very short, about an hour and a half. At the begginning of the game it tells you it's best to have headphones on and an hour and a half of free time to finish it in one sitting to get the full effect. This I absolutely recommend doing. With this game a lot is left up the the imagination of the player which I love but many people who need hand holding or have never enjoyed a good cliffhanger in a book do not appreciate. It is a great game for what it is and it has psychological elements although very subtle. The story feels slow but in fact isn't. The game itself is 1 1/2 hours. Depending on how you play and if you're a completionist or have to explore everything the pacing is basically based on how you play. I enjoyed this title and highly recommend. I mean, come on, $3 bucks. It's great.

A side scrolling mystery game where you wake up in a strange place, amidst strange circumstances, and must discover what has happened. With 'retro-styled graphics' and a simple interface, Home essentially lives and dies on its narrative and atmosphere.

One of those is better than the other.

Let's start with the atmosphere. Very little of the screen is visible, relying on your flashlight to illuminate your immediate surroundings. I think this works well, and helps build tension -- especially in new areas, or when the (sparse) sound effects kick in.

At the beginning of each area, there's a moment of unease as we -- like our protagonist (?) -- don't quite understand what's happening. Unfortunately, the longer we spend in one place, the more the reused environments and lack of interaction exposes the threadbare locations. Honestly, each screen has maybe one thing to examine, or interact with, and the whole thing is stretched longer than it should be.

That is the perfect segue back to the narrative. The mystery is pretty standard, and depending on what items you pick up, or how you answer the binary choices (Blablablabla. Yes or No?), things will change, but not nearly as much as I would like. Furthermore, some of the choices clearly align with the developers' intended canon, and others are likely to illicit a Really?" response from gamers.

To be frank
date: I would have preferred a smaller
recommended: more focused game with a dedicated narrative and more interaction (see Gone Home
hoursPlayed: or at least improve the branching paths like in Telltale's games). As it stands
voteText: it was an interesting experiment but not one I'll dwell on

reviewText: I love Home. Home is amazing. There's only so much I can say for fear of spoilers, but the slow, creeping exploration of a series of terrible events of questionable reality goes hand in hand with the pixel art style's leaving things to imagination. The impact of different choices on the game's progression and outcome adds another layer of replay value, and I love how much of the outcome is left to the player's interpretation and action rather than a set story.\n\nIf you can, check out the website for the game once you've finished, as there are some interesting bits integrated there as well. Great game, great price, and it's a fairly quick run from start to finish even if you're going in blind.

Huh.   This game was weird.  It's like Choose-Your-Own-Adventure, where all of your choices influence the ending.  The playthrough takes about an hour.  Kinda interesting game, but not interesting enough to do multiple replays to see what kind of endings are possible.

Despite s*** graphics, it was actually decently scary in the dark w/ headphones.

Maybe a buy for ~$0.50, like sell some trading cards for it.

Home reminds me of the games I played on my uncle's computer as a kid back in the 80s and that isn't a bad thing. Back before games became all about high poly counts and over the top action, there was an elegance in their simplicity. Obviously this wasn't always the case. There were plenty of terrible games back then as well but there was something about the style of video games back then that made for a memorable experience.

Much like a good mystery novel leaves you with more questions than answers and doesn't give away the entire story, the video games of my childhood were entertaining during play but often left you with plenty of things to ponder long afterward. You'd wonder about that one-off robot with one line of dialogue and where he came from. You'd lay awake in your bed trying to figure out if there were more secrets hidden in that dark cave your just finished passing through.

Home feels like an homage to that era of gaming... an era where one's imagination was as much a part of the experience as the production itself.

I'm not surprised to see a fair number of people giving Home negative reviews but I hope the developer doesn't take them to heart. I've read several of these negative critiques and to be perfectly honest the bulk of them simply have no appreciation for games that aren't multi-million dollar titles produced by teams numbering in the hundreds. These are the same folks who can't appreciate most indie films because they don't know how to process a movie that doesn't spoon feed them the plot between explosions. I don't fault them for it. They simply don't know any better.

I tip my hat to you Benjamin Rivers. Well done. What we have here is a unique piece of retro-styled choose-your-own-adventure story telling and it is beautiful in its simplicity and originality.

Short and sweet for a good price.

The atmosphere is excellent and the story is fairly twisted. Left me wanting more (in a good way).

Highly recommended for fans of Horror and Indie titles.

reviewText: Great little game with an open ending that leaves your imagination turning for hours. I'm gonna give Home a high rating because this kind of game, even though brief and with only 5 bottons, shows us that games can be more than just long-winded first-person-shooters with over-the-top graphics. Home pulls at the heart strings in a simple and creative way, using only 8 bit graphics and good-old-fashioned who-done-it storytelling - 9 out of 10.

A somewhat good story, a guy wakes up in some random guys house cant remember how he got there.  Then you spend the rest of the game trying to figured out what happened that night.   Takes about 3-4 play throughs to get all of the achievements.  Creaking pipes are supposed to scare you somehow, other than that, zero horror.  I recommend only buying this game on sale.
